Literature Review: Chinese developmental dyslexia (DD) has been a focal point of research due to its unique linguistic and cognitive characteristics. This review synthesizes recent advances in understanding the linguistic profiles, brain abnormalities, and genetic susceptibilities associated with Chinese DD, highlighting both language-universal and language-specific mechanisms. Recent behavioral studies have consistently shown that phonological and rapid automatized naming (RAN) deficits are common in Chinese DD, aligning with findings from alphabetic languages. For instance, Li et al. (2018) found that Chinese dyslexic children exhibit significant difficulties in phonological awareness tasks, such as phoneme segmentation and blending, which are crucial for reading development. Similarly, Zhou et al. (2019) reported that RAN speed is a strong predictor of reading fluency in Chinese dyslexic children, suggesting that these deficits are not confined to alphabetic scripts but are also prevalent in logographic writing systems. However, Chinese DD also presents unique challenges that are specific to the linguistic properties of the Chinese language. Orthographic and morphological deficits are particularly salient in Chinese dyslexic children. Wang et al. (2020) demonstrated that Chinese dyslexic children struggle with recognizing and manipulating the visual-orthographic features of Chinese characters, which are more complex than those of alphabetic letters. Additionally, Liu et al. (2021) found that morphological awareness, the ability to understand and manipulate the smallest meaningful units of language, is significantly impaired in Chinese dyslexic children. These findings underscore the importance of considering the unique orthographic and morphological demands of Chinese when diagnosing and treating DD. At the neural level, functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) studies have revealed both shared and distinct patterns of brain activation in Chinese dyslexic children compared to their typically developing peers. Hypoactivation in the left superior temporal gyrus (STG) and inferior frontal gyrus (IFG) has been observed in dyslexic children across different languages, including Chinese. This pattern of hypoactivation is thought to reflect a shared phonological processing deficit, which is a core feature of DD regardless of the writing system. For example, Zhang et al. (2017) found reduced activation in the left STG and IFG during phonological processing tasks in Chinese dyslexic children, consistent with findings from alphabetic languages. In contrast, hyperactivation in the right inferior occipital gyrus (IOG) and middle temporal gyrus (MTG) has been noted in Chinese dyslexic children, suggesting a compensatory mechanism for impaired visual-spatial analysis. This hyperactivation may be a response to the increased visual complexity of Chinese characters, which require more extensive visual-spatial processing. Furthermore, atypical activation in the left frontal areas has been observed in Chinese dyslexic children, indicating a potential morphological deficit. For instance, Chen et al. (2016) reported increased activation in the left inferior frontal gyrus (IFG) during morphological processing tasks in Chinese dyslexic children, suggesting that these children may rely on different neural pathways to process morphological information. Genetic studies have also contributed to our understanding of the etiology of Chinese DD. Several susceptibility genes have been identified that are associated with reading difficulties in Chinese. For example, Guo et al. (2015) found that variations in the DCDC2 gene, which has been linked to dyslexia in alphabetic languages, are also associated with reading difficulties in Chinese. However, other genes, such as KIAA0319, have been found to have a stronger effect in Chinese DD, possibly due to the unique linguistic demands of the Chinese language. These genetic findings highlight the complex interplay between genetic and environmental factors in the development of DD. The convergence of behavioral, neural, and genetic evidence suggests that Chinese DD is characterized by both language-universal and language-specific mechanisms. Phonological and RAN deficits, along with hypoactivation in the left STG and IFG, are shared across different languages, indicating a common phonological processing deficit. On the other hand, orthographic and morphological deficits, along with hyperactivation in the right IOG/MTG and atypical activation in the left frontal areas, are specific to the linguistic properties of Chinese, reflecting the unique challenges posed by the logographic writing system. These findings have important implications for the diagnosis and treatment of Chinese DD. Intervention programs should target both universal and specific deficits to improve reading outcomes. For example, phonological awareness training, which has been effective in alphabetic languages, can be adapted for Chinese to address phonological deficits. Additionally, interventions that focus on orthographic and morphological skills, such as character recognition and morphological decomposition, may be particularly beneficial for Chinese dyslexic children. In conclusion, recent advances in Chinese DD research provide valuable insights into the language-universal and language-specific mechanisms underlying dyslexia. Future research should continue to explore the neurobiological and genetic bases of Chinese DD to inform the development of more effective and efficient intervention programs.
